data.event: Immigrants from Britain and France settled a small village in 1858 which included a general store, school and mission church.

event.title: formed the Minneapolis Stockyards and Packing Company in 1888

data.event: As railroads were established in the area, millers in Minneapolis formed the Minneapolis Stockyards and Packing Company in 1888.

The venture included Minneapolis figures such as streetcar magnate Thomas Lowry, flour millers John Sargent Pillsbury, Senator William D. Washburn, ex-Minneapolis Mayor W.H. Eustis, and industrialist W.H. Dunwoody. As the village grew in prominence, it was incorporated on January 20, 1891.
Each August, a city festival celebrates this heritage, called the Stockyard Days and is held at Long Lake Park.
